mastery_profiles.name: Core Concept (CBSE)
mastery_profiles.intent: Solid understanding with common misconceptions removed.

mastery_profiles.name: Core Fluency (speed + accuracy)
mastery_profiles.intent: Fast, reliable execution for school tests and early exam prep.

mastery_profiles.name: EAPCET Foundation
mastery_profiles.intent: Algebra/geometry fluency building blocks with time discipline.

session_arc.rule: 2-3 retrieval items from past mastered atoms (spaced review).
1 misconception-probe + 1 representation item for today's atom.
1 worked example with 'hide steps' toggle; learner predicts next step.
1 novel context item; require estimate/check step.
quick self-explain: 'what trick helped' + confidence rating.

adaptation_rules.then: increase_difficulty or introduce interleaving with neighbor atom

interleaving_policy.after_mastery: mix 20-30% items from adjacent atoms and prerequisites
interleaving_policy.rule: never give >3 identical template types consecutively

spaced_review_scheduler.promotion_rule: advance interval when item correct with low hint and confidence>=3
spaced_review_scheduler.demotion_rule: if wrong, back to previous interval and tag misconception

derived_metrics.mastery_probability: Bayesian update using correctness + template weight + transfer weight
derived_metrics.misconception_rate: wrong answers mapped to misconception_id / attempts
derived_metrics.transfer_index: accuracy on transfer items vs core items
derived_metrics.forgetting_risk: time since last correct vs interval schedule

generation_prompts.global_system_prompt: You are an expert Grade 7 CBSE + Olympiad math item writer. Generate questions that measure understanding, not guessing. Always include: clear stem, required data for the template, correct answer, solution steps, misconception tags (when applicable), and a short transfer follow-up. Keep English simple (India). Avoid trick wording unless the atom is Olympiad.
global_constraints: Every item must map to exactly one atom_id and one template_id.
Numbers should be grade-appropriate; avoid heavy fractions unless atom is fractions/rational.
Include a quick estimation or check step in the solution when meaningful.
For girls/teens: keep contexts respectful and varied (sports, science, art, shopping, coding, travel), avoid stereotypes.
Avoid 'glitz' dependencies: interaction should provide mathematical insight.

template_prompt_recipes.prompt: Create a two-tier item: Tier-1 asks for the answer; Tier-2 asks 'why' with 4 reason options including 2 common misconceptions from the atom's misconception list.
Write a short incorrect worked solution (2-4 steps) that contains exactly one targeted misconception. Ask learner to identify the error type and correct the step.
Ask learner to place a value on a number line. Include line_min/max and a target_value. Provide a solution that explains placement and comparisons.
Generate a multi-step problem and provide an expected step sequence (3-6 steps). Steps must be checkable and not too open-ended.
Generate a novel context question using the same concept but different surface features. Provide a 1-sentence reflection prompt: 'What was similar to the earlier problem?'

data.description: Unique facts for this item. Must satisfy Template Library data_contract for template_id.

answer_key.description: Unique correct answer and accepted variants for this item.

misconception_ids.description: Optional stable misconception IDs from Core misconception_library.

context_tags.description: Optional surface tags for content analysis (e.g., cricket, fashion, biology).

json_schemas.validation_pipeline_notes: Composable validation: base schema (Assessment) + template data contract (Template Library) + curriculum constraints (Core).

notes_for_engineering_path.why_now: EAPCET is years away, but algebra manipulation, coordinate thinking, and geometry reasoning are built early so later trigonometry/graphs feel natural.
notes_for_engineering_path.weekly_micro_sprints: 2 short timed sets/week (6-8 minutes) to build calm speed without stress.

v3_changes: Added logic_bridge: mastery and remediation resolved via Core->Assessment and Template Library.
Added scaffolding_strategies and misconception_strategy_defaults to eliminate per-item hint duplication.
Updated base question schema to a lean structure; template validates item.data.

fetch_hierarchy.core_curriculum: context, outcomes, prerequisites, misconception library, template recommendations
fetch_hierarchy.template_library: display defaults, telemetry requirements, per-template data contract
fetch_hierarchy.assessment_guide: mastery standards, sequencing rules, remediation strategy library

resolution_order: Validate item root against question_item_base_schema (this file).
Lookup atom_id in Core: allowed templates, prerequisites, misconception defaults, mastery_profile_id.
Lookup mastery_profile_id here: evidence requirements, thresholds, review cadence.
If incorrect, map misconception_id -> scaffolding strategy and render the appropriate recovery ladder.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Clarify the rule with a tiny example
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Default when no specific strategy matches.

hint_ladder.text: Restate the rule in one sentence and try a 1-step example with small numbers.
Show a worked micro-example, then ask the student to finish a parallel one.
Provide a partially completed solution and ask for the missing step.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Number-line grounding for sign and direction
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix sign confusion, negative moves, and ordering.

hint_ladder.text: Place the numbers on a number line. Right is bigger, left is smaller.
Convert the operation into hops. Start value stays fixed; hops move from it.
Estimate first: should the answer be >0 or <0? Then compute.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Percent base changes (discount then tax)
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix errors where percent is taken on the wrong base.

hint_ladder.text: Percent always means 'of the current base'. Identify the base after each step.
Use a two-row table: Step | Base | Percent | Amount.
Rewrite as multipliers: after discount multiply by (1−d), then tax multiply by (1+t).

scaffolding_strategies.name: Reciprocal and fraction division
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix flipping the wrong fraction or mixing rules.

hint_ladder.text: Only flip the divisor (the fraction you divide by).
Rewrite division as multiplication by reciprocal, then multiply tops and bottoms.
Simplify before multiplying (cross-cancel) to reduce errors.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Undo order in equations (reverse operations)
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix doing division before subtraction, or changing one side only.

hint_ladder.text: Undo operations in reverse order. First undo +/−, then ×/÷.
Whatever you do to one side, do to the other to keep balance.
Substitute your x back into the original equation to verify.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Parentheses and distributive property
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix dropping parentheses or partial distribution.

hint_ladder.text: Multiply the outside term by every term inside the bracket.
Use area/tiles model: each product becomes a rectangle area.
Test with a small x value to see if expressions match.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Combine like terms correctly
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix mixing unlike terms or changing variables.

hint_ladder.text: Only terms with exactly the same variable part can be combined.
Group like terms (same variable) before adding coefficients.
Plug in x=1 to check if simplification changed the value.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Angle relationships
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix vertical, complementary, supplementary, straight line sums.

hint_ladder.text: Use the one rule that applies: straight line = 180°, around a point = 360°, vertical angles equal.
Mark equal angles and write an equation before calculating.
Re-draw the same structure rotated; angle relationships stay the same.
For a triangle, sum of two sides must be greater than the third.
Sort sides: a≤b≤c. Check a+b>c only.
Imagine two sticks trying to meet: if they just touch (a+b=c), it collapses.

scaffolding_strategies.name: Order-first for median and range
scaffolding_strategies.intent: Fix statistics errors from unsorted data.

hint_ladder.text: Always order the data first.
Pair from ends toward the center to find the middle.
For odd count: 1 middle. For even: average the two middles.
Metric units scale by powers of 10 (×10, ×100, ×1000).
Use a unit ladder and count steps. Right multiply, left divide.
Sanity check: converting to smaller units increases the number.
